Award.AwardTitle: Correlation of Molecular Architecture and Fluid Dynamic Properties within Solid-Fluid Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Analytical and Surface Chemistry Program supports the research program of Prof. Jeanne Pemberton at the University of Arizona. Prof. Pemberton and her students aim to determine the interfacial molecular structure in solid-fluid interfaces formed with simple and complex fluids and elucidate the dependence of interfacial fluid dynamic properties on that molecular structure. Control of solid-fluid interfaces necessitates development of an understanding of molecular structure-function relationships that govern the static and dynamic properties of these interfaces. Although the theoretical framework for interfacial fluid dynamics is in hand and recent computational and theoretical efforts have predicted interfacial fluid dynamic behavior in considerable detail, experimental investigations in which interfacial molecular structure is defined and correlated with interfacial dynamic properties are sparse. In this work, the role of surface chemistry and morphology, and interfacial molecular organization and structure in templating, unique interfacial fluid structure will be studied using optical spectroscopies and correlated with interfacial dynamics. These studies will also be extended to complex fluids, including polymers. Effects of altered dynamic properties within the interface in both the lateral and vertical directions will also be studied as will effects related to the entanglement of molecules within the interface.

This highly interdisciplinary effort serves as a fertile training ground for students who will see the direct relevance of their chemical research in areas as diverse as fluid physics, mechanical engineering, bioanalysis and biotechnology, and environmental science. Results of this work will be broadly disseminated, both orally and in writing, in venues frequented by these diverse communities. Since this work lays the foundation for a deeper molecular understanding of fluid properties, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students on this project will spend at least one semester working with local high school chemistry teachers to develop introductory modules on the molecular structure and dynamic properties of fluids appropriate for the regular high school chemistry and high school Advanced Placement chemistry levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Solid-fluid interfaces play critical roles in many important technologies and processes. Such interfaces are also important in biologically-related systems and materials. Despite this importance, little is known about molecular structure-fluid dynamic relationships of such interfaces even though it is increasingly understood that true control of these interfaces will come only as molecular structure-function relationships that govern the static and dynamic properties of these interfaces are elucidated more fully. Toward this end, this effort had the following major goals:

  • determine interfacial molecular structure in solid-fluid interfaces formed with simple and complex fluids using a strategy for physical isolation of ultrathin (nanometer) fluid films on solids by forced dewetting, a method developed previously in the Principal Investigator’s (PI’s) laboratory;
  • correlate interfacial fluid dynamic properties with interfacial molecular structure;
  • define fluid microviscosity within a solid-liquid interface as a function of distance from the surface and compare it to the viscosity properties of the bulk fluid; and
  • use fluorescence spectroscopy to explore flow field penetration of solvents into polymer surfaces.

We achieved significant progress on each of these goals. First, we refined a quantitative theory to describe the thicknesses of residual thin films created by forced dewetting based on long range forces as embodied in the total disjoining pressure, and successfully applied this theory to several types of chemical systems with different contributions to the disjoining pressure. Using surface spectroscopy, we defined molecular composition of fluids in interfaces near solid surfaces and identified structural attributes that distinguish the interfacial fluid from the bulk. Our work revealed that fluid composition can be extensively altered relative to the bulk near a solid surface, and that very close to the surface, the fluid can be so ordered that it takes on solid-like characteristics.

We explored the dynamic properties of interfacial fluids through study of viscosity using fluorescence spectroscopy and demonstrated that, as with molecular structure, the interfacial dynamic properties can differ significantly from those of the bulk. Our work demonstrated that viscosity changes in bulk solution are muted in interfaces near a solid, becoming more muted closer to the surface. These changes could be due to changes in interfacial composition or molecular structure or both. Future work will unravel these dependencies.

We initiated studies to explore the extent to which flow fields penetrate into polymer surfaces. In studies of thin polymer films, we explored changes in fluorescence response of a dye imbedded in the polymer brought about by interaction with species in a solution flowing in laminar flow over the top of the polymer surface as a function of flow velocity. Initial results suggest that the flow field does not penetrate into the polymer per se, but instead, the increased pressure necessary to generate a given flow velocity increases the rate of penetration of the fluid into the polymer by a random statistical process known as percolation.

 

Broader Impacts

This work is of fundamental importance and will support advances in modern technologies and challenges such as lubrication, microfluidic/nanofluidic devices, microelectromechanical systems, and contaminant transport through soil. This highly interdisciplinary effort serves as a fertile training ground for students who see the direct relevance of their chemical research in areas as diverse as fluid physics, mechanical engineering, bioanalysis and biotechnology, and environmental science.

Toward this end, this effort had the following major goals: determine interfacial molecular structure in solid-fluid interfaces formed with simple and complex fluids using a strategy for physical isolation of ultrathin (nanometer) fluid films on solids by forced dewetting, a method developed previously in the Principal InvestigatorÆs (PIÆs) laboratory; correlate interfacial fluid dynamic properties with interfacial molecular structure; define fluid microviscosity within a solid-liquid interface as a function of distance from the surface and compare it to the viscosity properties of the bulk fluid; and use fluorescence spectroscopy to explore flow field penetration of solvents into polymer surfaces.
